Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: new car B: promotion C: boredom D: impatience E: pressure<n>Answer: B: promotion<n><n>Input: He was good at traditional science but excelled at social science, his favorite subject was what? Choices:  A: geography B: history studies C: math D: religion E: dancing<n>Answer: B: history studies<n><n>Input: Jan wasn't very good at studying.  What might help him study better? Choices:  A: having a bigger brain B: headaches C: inspiration D: more intelligence E: understanding<n>Answer: D: more intelligence<n><n>Input: The cat was wild but like all others he was always read for a cat what? Choices:  A: stealing B: four legs C: tuna fish D: food now E: nap<n>Answer: E: nap<n><n>### Input:What do all rooms facing outside have? Choices:  A: square shape B: different sizes C: flowers D: doors and windows E: high walls<n><n>### Response:		 They all have high walls<n><n>## 2. If/Else<n>- In if/else there are two possibilities. The first possible outcome will be considered in the if part and the other is considered in the else part.<n>- Conditionally, two actions can be performed based on an input.<n>- A statement can start with a double vertical line ( || )<n>- Condition:<n>  - You can test any value (variable, constant or expressions) in a program<n>- A boolean expression can be used in the condition<n>- If the condition is true then only the if part will execute.<n>- If the condition doesn't fit then only the else part will execute.<n><n>### Sample:<n>Input: Is the value of a boolean variable? Choices:  a) True b) False<n>Input: If I was in the USA? Choices: 1) Yes<n>Input: Get an output for a<n>Answer: a<n><n>## 3. In/Output<n>- An I/O is a two-way communication between the program and the user.<n>- The output variable is the input variable.<n>- There are 3 ways to perform an operation.<n>- It will not print the values if the size of the array and the value entered is odd.<n>- You cannot print a string in a string in a computer program.<n>  <n>### Sample: <n>``` C<n>    //  Sample to display numbers on two sides of console<n>    int i;<n>    // number of array elements<n>    int n = 7;<n>    printf("\t");<n>    for (i = 1; i <= n; i++)<n>    {<n>        printf("%d ", i);<n>    }<n>    printf("\n");<n>  <n>    n = 7; //  number of array elements<n>  <n>  <n>    int data[n]; //  array<n>  <n>    scanf("%d", &data[0]); //  read an integer value from a given location and store it in array data<n>    for (i=0; i<n; i++)<n>    printf("%d ", data[i]); //  display values of array elements<n>   /* You cannot display the values in a string in a string here,<n>     because it requires to declare an array of length 3*/<n>```<n><n>### Output: 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: He fantasied about getting a what while driving to work and the pros and cons of the extra responsibilities and benefits? Choices:  A: stealing B: four legs C: tuna fish D: food now E: nap<n>Answer: E: nap<n><n>### Input:Ice fishing can be done surprisingly far out most winters on what greatest of the Michigan's greats? Choices:  A: pond B: underwater C: aquarium D: lake superior E: body of water<n><n>### Response:		E: body of water<n>### Demonstraion:<n>Response:Ice fishing is often used when a frozen lake, river, pond or tarn (a small pond). The activity known as ___ __ usually involves a fishing rod held in a small shack made of ice which can be situated on the surface of the water, or in the case of ___ ___, within. It is not uncommon to drill holes into the ice to make fishing easier.<n><n>![input image](../assets/images/Instructions.jpg)<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration:Write an answer that makes sense for a given response.<n>Response:When fishing from on the ice itself, the method is called ___ __ and the shack that the fishing rod is housed in is called ___ __. Choices:  A: geography B: history studies C: math D: religion E: dancing<n>Answer: B: history studies<n><n>Input: Jan wasn't very good at studying.  What might help him study better? Choices:  A: having a bigger brain B: headaches C: inspiration D: more intelligence E: understanding<n>Answer: D: more intelligence<n><n>Input: The cat was wild but like all others he was always read for a cat what? Choices:  A: stealing B: four legs C: tuna fish D: food now E: nap<n>Answer: E: nap<n><n>### Input:People were talking on the corner, who were they talking with? Choices:  A: god B: mix C: with people D: have friends E: see people<n><n>### Response:		They were talking with friends<n><n>### Input- Output<n>#### You write the request.  <n>```<n>Request.<n>Write a statement(s) that describes the task to be completed.<n>``` <n>Input:  <n>```<n>Input: What are your plans for after work?<n>``` <n>Output:  <n>```<n>Plans: <n>I want to get a new car.<n>I need to get a new car or new job.<n><n>The car will be better in every way, but how it'd be more expensive.<n>I want to get it done quickly. <n>I need to complete it soon...<n>I want to not worry about what to do..<n><n>```<n>Plans, continued....<n><n>```<n>Output:<n>I'd get the payment for the car from the bank and go to buy it.<n>I'd have a plan for the extra money and work on it.<n>```<n><n>### What is a program?<n>Ideas are written in words. Instructions are written in code(words).  Code tells the computer what to do. Code is not very expressive.  <n>Code is like words.<n><n>A program has instructions for tasks, like a recipe for how to cook breakfast.<n><n>A computer is programmed to do tasks.  When it doesn't do the right task, it gets errors.<n><n>```<n>What are my favorite pains, when?<n>```<n><n><img src="images/240_ComputersDo_programs_not_commands.JPG"/><n><n><img src = "images/2401_ComputersDo_Programs_Not_Commands.png"/><n><n><n><img src ="images/2402_what_computers_do_programs-not_commands.png"/><n><n><img  src ="images/250_HowComputersWorkTutorial1.png"/><n><n>#### The Computer is programmed and it does what it is told.<n><n>#### If you ask a computer to do something, it would only do it that one time.  Instead, a program tells it to do it and when. <n>#### The program can be run again and again.<n><n>### If you want it to remember and do more tasks<n>Keep asking it to remember and do the same tasks and it gets it wrong. It gets errors.
